objective: Complete backlog and sprint creation for AgentFlow SPARC adoption with comprehensive user stories and 2-week execution plan
inputs: memory-bank/productContext.md - Comprehensive system overview and architecture
project/AgentFlow/control/graph.yaml - SPARC workflow phases and current status
README.md - System features and technical requirements
acceptance_criteria: backlog.yaml validates against schema and contains comprehensive user stories mapped to SPARC phases
sprint.yaml contains focused 2-week plan with proper DoR/DoD and realistic capacity
User stories properly categorized and prioritized by business value and risk
All stories include detailed acceptance criteria and dependencies
Sprint plan aligns with current SPARC phase (research) and unblocks next phases
HANDOFF/V1 file created with complete story list and sprint plan summary
artifacts: project/AgentFlow/control/backlog.yaml - Comprehensive backlog with 47 user stories across 13 epics
project/AgentFlow/control/sprint.yaml - 2-week sprint plan with 3 committed stories
dependencies: SPARC workflow graph and phase definitions

next.intent: Execute research sprint stories to gather decision-grade sources for critical technical decisions
Validate research findings and ensure â‰¥95% confidence for architectural decisions

notes: Successfully created comprehensive backlog and sprint for AgentFlow SPARC adoption. The backlog contains 47 user stories organized across 13 epics that map to the complete SPARC workflow from research through SRE implementation. Sprint 001 focuses on the critical research foundation needed to make informed architecture decisions, with 21 story points across 3 high-priority stories. The plan balances research depth with validation to ensure decisions are well-informed and cross-verified before proceeding to architecture design.
risk_flags: Research findings may identify significant technical challenges requiring architecture changes
Performance targets may need adjustment based on research validation
Multi-framework integration complexity may exceed initial estimates
Security requirements may impact development velocity and architectural decisions
